The Tubenose Goby is a small, bottom-dwelling invasive fish that lives among the aquatic vegetation found in nearshore waters of lakes and rivers. Since its discovery in North America in the late 1980s, Tubenose Goby have been found in a few locations in the Great Lakes. To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Tubenose Goby as bait, and never transfer live bait between waterbodies. It is against the law. Scientists are concerned about the possible long-term effects, because it can beat resident fish for habitat and food. This is a real concern for bottom-dwelling fishes, like Rainbow Darter and Northern Madtom.
For more information, or to report sightings, please visit http://ow.ly/KiLk30h9x2w

The Round Goby is a small, bottom-dwelling invasive fish that has unfortunately spread through all five Great Lakes in less than a decade. To prevent the spread of this invasive species, never buy or use Round Goby as bait, and never live transfer bait between waterbodies, which are against the law. They prefer waters with rocky and sandy bottoms, and feed aggressively on insects, molluscs, and other small organisms. They have even been known to eat juvenile freshwater mussels, many of which are at-risk! Round Goby are also found in some inland waters in southern Ontario such as Lake Simcoe, the Trent River, Rice Lake, and parts of the Otonabee River. status_message: Canada's first marine biological research station began operations in St. Andrews, New Brunswick in 1899. St. Andrews was chosen because of the diverse biological and physical environment in Passamaquoddy Bay and the Bay of Fundy and its proximity to important commercial fisheries for herring, groundfish and invertebrate species.
